Award.AwardTitle: CS10K: TeachIT - Scaling Mobile CSP Professional Development Online

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The College of St. Scholastica proposes to develop, implement, and evaluate TeachIT-CSP, a CS10K project designed to provide computer science education professional development to high school teachers throughout the nation. This project will adapt the Mobile Computer Science Principles (Mobile CSP) curriculum developed by Trinity College and offer it to teachers via a summer online course, complemented by ongoing online mentoring and support during the school year. TeachIT-CSP will scale the Mobile CSP professional development to reach at least 180 teachers over three years, and possibly many more. The planned online format will be particularly helpful in allowing teachers from rural and underfunded schools to participate in professional development and a supportive learning community, as they achieve mastery of new teaching content and methods. This project will prepare participants to teach the Computer Science Principles (AP CSP) curriculum in their classrooms and provide support to them in this process.

TeachIT-CSP goals include (1) bringing teacher professional development to scale with an engaging and effective open online course that focuses on computer science concepts using Mobile CSP curriculum, (2) providing pedagogical support to help teachers incorporate best practices that improve student learning outcomes in computer science and support underrepresented populations, and (3) developing an open and sharable repository of video exemplars of computer science teachers demonstrating evidence-based practices. The evaluation will compare results between online and face-to-face PD focusing on the significant areas identified by the Mobile CSP project and the CSP framework. The project will evaluate teacher performance using videos and teacher reflections instead of classroom observations. An external evaluator will adapt surveys for use with teachers engaged in online PD.

ProgramReference.Text: Computer Science for All (CS for All)

POR.DRECONTENT:
Computer science has traditionally been a field dominated by a few, but it is critical to our nation?s future that students of all identities and backgrounds understand and participate in computing. The Computer Science Principles (CSP) course was designed to engage all students through a breadth-first introduction to computing, covering not only programming but also data, the internet, and how technology has impacted our society. Mobile CSP is an effort to broaden participation in computing by supporting efforts to teach the CS Principles course. The TeachIT project builds on the success of Mobile CSP, initially by providing online curriculum and professional development (PD) to high school teachers across the country. Currently, the project is maintaining the online curriculum and providing PD in several formats (e.g. online, hybrid, in-person) and lengths (45 and 65 hours) to meet the needs of teachers. Of note is that the online PD achieved similar teacher and student outcomes to other PD formats (hybrid and in-person). This grant had three main goals. 

 

Goal 1 - Online Teacher Professional Development (PD): Bring to scale the Mobile CSP curriculum for teachers and students in an engaging and effective open online course format focusing on CS concepts.

The Mobile CSP curriculum and teacher materials are available for free to anyone online and can be reused through a Creative Commons license. The project team provided Mobile CSP PD to 476 teachers, including academic year support. As the project grew, a PD facilitator training was created to prepare and support facilitators as they led teacher PD with over 47 facilitators trained. Through the PD, teachers gained CS content knowledge and learned how to use evidence-based pedagogies for supporting students historically underrepresented in computing. Teachers completed a final exam at the end of the PD with average scores of 80% across all years of the project. Teachers reported high confidence in using evidence-based pedagogies such as pair programming (76%), growth mindset (92%), welcoming environments (92%), and actively recruiting students (77%). Over 60% of teachers who completed Mobile CSP PD taught the course in their schools, and even more teachers have used the curriculum and resources to teach the course without the PD. 

 

Goal 2 - Student Learning: Provide effective online professional development and ongoing support to help teachers incorporate best practices that improve student learning outcomes in CS and support underrepresented populations.

Students taking the Mobile CSP course often complete the Advanced Placement (AP) CSP exam, where they regularly outperform the national average of all students (Table 1). This is also true for targeted demographic groups of those underrepresented in computing (Table 2).

 

Table 1. AP CSP Exam Results (Source: College Board; passing scores are 3, 4, or 5)

Year       National       National Pass Rate   Mobile CSP   Mobile CSP Pass Rate

2017       43,780                74.4%                  3,531                  80.1%

2018       72,187                71.2%                  4,038                  78.7%

2019       94,360                71.7%                  4,731                  78.1%



Table 2. 2019 AP CSP Pass Rate by Demographic Group
(Source: College Board; passing scores are 3, 4, or 5)

Group                      National                           Mobile CSP 

Female                     69.4%                                78.1%

Black/African Am      41.9%                                46.8%

Hispanic/Latino         54.4%                                61.6%

2 or more races         76.4%                               83.4%

 

At the end of the course, Mobile CSP students also report positive attitudes towards computing and a belief that they can persist in computing. For example, on a 5-point Likert scale, students agree that CS has the potential to positively impact their community (4.25) and that they will do well in CS (3.84).  

 

Goal 3 - Video Repository: Develop an open and shareable repository of video exemplars that capture CS teachers demonstrating evidence-based practices.

As part of the online PD, during the academic year, teachers recorded and shared two videos of a lesson in their classroom for reflection with their PD cohort. Overall, teachers reported that this task encouraged reflection to identify strengths and weaknesses as well as built community with their cohort by watching other teachers? videos. The project team developed a rubric for identifying evidence-based pedagogy in the videos, analyzing a sample of the videos; rubric categories included inclusivity, growth mindset, collaboration, welcoming physical environment, accessibility, CS content knowledge and understanding, and effective classroom management. While teachers rated their use of the pedagogy higher in the reflections, researchers found less evidence of them in the videos and identified areas of improvement for the PD. Some of the classroom footage was used to create videos to support the professional development, including one on pair programming. The team worked with PD facilitators to gather additional footage and created four additional videos on Student Collaboration & Engagement, Classroom Culture, Brainwriting, and Classroom Management. Many of these resources are now available to any CS teacher at inclusivecsteaching.org, a website featuring evidence-based pedagogy for CS teachers.

Modified by: Jennifer L Rosato
